stem: A 6-year-old child with a history of asthma is brought to the emergency department with increased wheezing and shortness of breath. The child's respiratory rate is 32 breaths/min, heart rate is 120 bpm, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. The nurse should administer [medication1] via nebulizer and [intervention2] to improve oxygenation. It is also important to assess the child's [assessment3] to monitor the effectiveness of the treatment.

rationale.correct: Albuterol is a beta-2 adrenergic agonist, causing bronchodilation by relaxing smooth muscles in the airways, thus alleviating wheezing and shortness of breath. Oxygen therapy is crucial to counteract hypoxemia by increasing the partial pressure of oxygen in the alveoli, facilitating oxygen diffusion into the bloodstream. Assessing breath sounds post-intervention helps evaluate the effectiveness of bronchodilation and oxygen delivery, identifying improvements or the need for further intervention. Continuous monitoring prevents respiratory failure. ClinicalPearl: Early intervention in asthma exacerbations can prevent respiratory failure. QuestionTrap: Selecting antibiotics is incorrect as they are ineffective against asthma, a condition of airway inflammation and constriction, not bacterial infection. Mnemonic: "Open Airways with Albuterol and Oxygen."
rationale.mnemonic: Open Airways with Albuterol and Oxygen.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect options would not directly address the immediate needs of a child experiencing an asthma exacerbation. For example, antibiotics are not indicated unless there is evidence of a bacterial infection. Restricting fluids could worsen dehydration, and monitoring blood pressure is less critical than assessing respiratory status in this situation.
rationale.questionTrap: Students may choose options that are generally good nursing care but not the priority in an acute asthma exacerbation.
clinicalPearls: Early recognition and treatment of asthma exacerbations are crucial to prevent respiratory failure.
Always assess the child's response to treatment and adjust interventions as needed.

itemContext.sbar: S: Nurse Amy calling from the Emergency Department. I'm calling about Alex Johnson, a 6-year-old male. B: Alex presented at 14:00 with increased wheezing and shortness of breath. He has a history of asthma, usually well-controlled with a daily inhaler. Mother reports symptoms started this morning and have been worsening despite using his rescue inhaler. A: Respiratory rate is 32 breaths/min, heart rate is 120 bpm, and SpO2 is 90% on room air. Significant wheezing is audible bilaterally. He is alert but anxious. R: I am requesting orders for nebulized albuterol and oxygen therapy. I would also like guidance on further management.

A: Respiratory rate is 32 breaths/min, heart rate is 120 bpm, and SpO2 is 90% on room air. Significant wheezing is audible bilaterally. He is alert but anxious. tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: Time: 14:00 Respiratory Rate: 32 breaths/min Heart Rate: 120 bpm SpO2: 90% on room air Temperature: 37.2°C (99.0°F) Blood Pressure: 110/70 mmHg

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: ABG (14:15): pH: 7.30 PaCO2: 50 mmHg PaO2: 60 mmHg HCO3: 24 mEq/L

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Alert but anxious, sitting upright. Respiratory: Significant wheezing audible bilaterally, increased work of breathing with nasal flaring and intercostal retractions. Cardiovascular: Tachycardia, regular rhythm. Skin: No cyanosis noted.

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: Chest X-Ray (14:30): Hyperinflation of lungs, no signs of pneumonia.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: Problem: Acute Asthma Exacerbation Goal: Improve oxygenation and reduce airway obstruction. Interventions: -Administer nebulized albuterol as ordered. -Administer oxygen to maintain SpO2 > 94%. -Monitor respiratory status and response to treatment. -Educate patient and family on asthma management.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Albuterol Nebulizer: -Dose: 2.5 mg -Route: Nebulized inhalation -Frequency: Every 20 minutes as needed Oxygen: -Route: Nasal cannula -Flow Rate: 2 L/min -Titrate to maintain SpO2 > 94%
